paper.title: Selecting an end user programming language for DSS development

author.org: Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA,

paper.publisher: Society for Information Management and The Management Information Systems Research Center
paper.abstract: Today managers and policy makers are confronted with an overwhelming range of choices of computer software to develop decision support systems (DSS). The authors argue that DSS language evaluation and selection should be a multi-step process involving most, if not all of the :[43],"End User Needs Assessment and Problem :[50],"Critical Success Factor :[54],"Feature Analysis and Capability :[59],"Demonstration Prototype :[62],"External User :[65],"Benchmark and Simulation :[69],"Programmer Productivity and :[43],"End User Orientation :[76],"objectives of each of these activities are described, as well as specific procedures for accomplishing them. In addition, the authors discuss the usefulness of a multi-disciplinary task force to accomplish the DSS language evaluation and selection process.
